data.description:
# Web3Stash
Web3Stash is a standard library to get a single api to connect to multiple decentralised storage service providers. If you are looking to connect to blockchain services like ipfs, pinata, nft.storage, arweave, bundlr, helia etc but don't want to read there docs and set them up individually, You can use this package to connect to any of these services. The best part is all the configuration settings and upload functions are almost same across all the services.

# How this library works and Ease Your Development

## Install the library
The official web3stash Node.js package. This is the easiest way to start developing with multiple decentralised storage service providers. 

```js
Install via NPM
npm install --save web3stash
```

## Importing and Using Package
Take a look at how you might import and use the web3Stash package:

```js
// require the webStash module
const {Web3Stash} = require('web3stash');
//or
import {Web3Stash} from 'web3stash';
// provide service name, config properties like privateKeys
const service = Web3Stash(<serviceName>, <config>, <configOptions>)
// Call the methods(Same for all services)
service.uploadJson(<jsonData>, <options>).then().catch()
service.uploadImage(<path to image>, <options>).then().catch()
service.uploadVideo(<path to video file>, <options>).then().catch()
service.uploadFile(<path to file>, <options>).then().catch()

```

### Start using services
Head to services tab in [docs](https://theblockchainchief.gitbook.io/web3stash/) page and pass config details based on the service you want to use. All services need same three things when initialising web3Stash as shown above:

```js
Web3Stash(<serviceName>, <config>, <configOptions>)
```

- serviceName(string) -  Here you have to put service you want to use like "PINATA", "ARWEAVE", "BUNDLR", etc in string format 


We have made this project opensource and planning to integrate more and more services and also add data streaming and chunk uploading for big files for all the services we support making data uploading to decentralized storage networks easy, efficient, fast, and scalable. 

We have been winner/Finalist at EthGlobal HackFS 2023.
data.title: Web3stash Library
Decentralized Library
data.description: This project outlines the creation of a decentralized library for web3 books and resources, which leverages blockchain technology and decentralized storage to provide a censorship-resistant, accessible, and verifiable platform for users to access and share educational and informational content.
data.problem: The need to implement more Web2 solutions into Web3 has necessitated this idea. Decentralized library is a no-censorship library where users go to read books and watch video books using the Web3 wallet. This books could be paid or tipped.
data.solution:
The following benefit awaits users of this project

Hundreds of Academic E-Books: The Library has more books than you could imagine. E-books repositories are decentralized (IPFS Storage).
Lot of Video-Books: The full video books are here for you. if you cannot read the ebook format, you can read your favorite textbooks by watching them (IPFS Storage).
No Political Censorship: No fear from the government of your country not allowing certain books. You can read or watch them here.
Learn and Earn: The very First decentralized Library where you LEARN and EARN.
Live Class Streaming: Lecturers / Teachers can use this platform to schedule live teaching and learning. just contact us
No Loss of Books: Prevent the accidental or intentional loss of information from human consciousness

Decentralized library, focused on sustainability and environmentally conscious content, can contribute to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs) in several ways:

Reduction of Physical Resources: Traditional libraries often require large amounts of paper, ink, and other physical resources to produce and distribute printed books and materials. By promoting digital resources and e-books, a decentralized library can significantly reduce the demand for these resources, resulting in fewer emissions associated with their production and transportation.
Energy Efficiency: Centralized data centers and physical libraries require substantial energy for heating, cooling, and maintaining the infrastructure. Decentralized libraries, powered by blockchain technology and distributed storage systems, can potentially operate with lower energy consumption, especially if the network uses renewable energy sources.
Minimized Transportation: Traditional library systems involve the distribution of physical books to various locations. This transportation contributes to GHG emissions due to the use of fossil fuels in the delivery process. A decentralized library eliminates the need for physical transportation, reducing emissions associated with the shipping of books and resources.
Reduced Deforestation: Decentralized libraries can discourage deforestation by advocating for the use of digital content rather than paper-based resources. Reduced demand for paper products can help protect forests and reduce the carbon emissions associated with deforestation.
Remote Access: By providing users with easy access to digital resources from anywhere in the world, a decentralized library can reduce the need for individuals to travel to physical libraries. Fewer trips to library locations mean fewer emissions from transportation.
Environmental Education: Decentralized libraries can curate content on environmental sustainability, climate change, and green technologies. By providing access to these resources, they can help educate the public about climate issues and inspire action to reduce GHG emissions.
Blockchain for Carbon Offsetting: Some blockchain projects and cryptocurrencies are exploring ways to support carbon offsetting initiatives. A decentralized library could potentially integrate with such initiatives to facilitate carbon offset donations or rewards for users engaged in sustainable practices.
Support for Green Initiatives: A decentralized library can serve as a platform for sharing information about local and global green initiatives and sustainability projects. It can connect users with resources on renewable energy, eco-friendly practices, and climate change mitigation efforts.
Peer-to-Peer Sharing: Decentralized libraries can encourage users to share resources with their peers, reducing the need to purchase new books or access new digital content. Sharing and peer-to-peer exchange can help minimize resource consumption and reduce the carbon footprint of producing new materials.
Data Security and Privacy: Ensuring data security and privacy can reduce the likelihood of data breaches or cyberattacks that could result in energy-intensive data recovery and restoration processes, thus minimizing associated GHG emissions.
In summary, a decentralized library that emphasizes sustainability and digital resources can help reduce GHG emissions by minimizing the demand for physical resources, decreasing energy consumption, reducing transportation-related emissions, and fostering environmental education and awareness. Such a library can play a valuable role in supporting global efforts to combat climate change and promote a more sustainable future.
data.missionSummary: A mission to serve as a serves as a starting point for a visionary project that can empower users with control over educational content in the web3 era while solving the Green House Gas (GHG) Emission
data.pathToTake: Want to grow through just grant funding

data.description:
## Overview

Library Protocol is an open-source book-sharing application that enables users to bring their physical libraries on-chain, lend books, and borrow books in a borderless way. It serves as a network connecting book and library owners with book lovers, readers, and curious minds.

For centuries, books have been the cornerstone of knowledge and intellectual progress. Libraries have preserved history, empowered thinkers, and shaped civilizations. But access to books remains limited by geography, availability, and ownership.

### *What if anyone, anywhere, could borrow books seamlessly—without borders?*

With Library Protocol, you can:
📚 Put your personal or institutional library onchain
🔗 Lend books securely using smart contracts
📖 Borrow books from anywhere without relying on centralized platforms
🛡 Leverage a reputation-based system for responsible borrowing

*The goal? To unlock knowledge for everyone, everywhere!*

[![1500x500.jpg](https://i.postimg.cc/Xq6LpcTS/1500x500.jpg)](https://postimg.cc/Vr4nhMfD) 

**Why Do We Need Onchain Libraries?**
In today’s world, access to books is restricted by several barriers:
❌ Physical limitations – Libraries and personal collections are confined by geography.
❌ High costs – Many valuable books remain unaffordable for students, researchers, and knowledge seekers.
❌ Trust issues – Traditional lending requires manual agreements with no enforcement mechanism.
❌ Lack of incentives – Book owners have little reason to share their collections openly.

Library Protocol solves these issues by introducing a decentralized, global book-sharing network where ownership, lending, and borrowing are managed transparently on-chain.

[![Screenshot-2025-03-08-010256.png](https://i.postimg.cc/3J3ng1bn/Screenshot-2025-03-08-010256.png)](https://postimg.cc/BtwT3T3K) 

**How Library Protocol Works**
Library Protocol is designed to be open, transparent, and accessible. Here's how it works:
📖 1. **Create Your Onchain Library**
- Connect your wallet and create your own onchain library.
- Register books you own (metadata like Title, Author, ISBN, Cover Image stored on IPFS).
- Each book is represented as an NFT for tracking purposes.

📚 2. **Lend Books Securely**
- List books from your library for lending.
- Set lending conditions (with or without collateral).
- Borrowers request books, and a smart contract handles agreements and collateral.

🔗 3. **Borrow Books from the Network**
- Browse available books across different libraries.
- Request to borrow, deposit collateral if required.
- Return books on time to maintain a strong reputation score.

🛡 4. **Trust & Reputation System** 
- Every borrower and lender has an onchain reputation score.
- Timely returns improve reputation, unlocking better lending terms.

[![Screenshot-2025-03-08-014352.png](https://i.postimg.cc/qqB0Vnj0/Screenshot-2025-03-08-014352.png)](https://postimg.cc/tZc8FsKm) 

### Built for Readers, Libraries, and the Future of Knowledge
Library Protocol is built for:
📖 **Readers & Learners** – Anyone seeking knowledge, from casual readers to researchers.
📚 **Book Enthusiasts** – Those who own physical books and want to share them.
🏛 **Libraries & Archives** – Institutions aiming to digitize collections and reach a global audience in novel ways.
👥 **Communities & Educators** – Groups looking to build decentralized knowledge-sharing hubs.
By bridging the physical and digital book world, Library Protocol creates a borderless knowledge ecosystem.

The future of libraries is on-chain. Library Protocol transforms your personal bookshelf into a gateway of global wisdom—a decentralized network that unites curious minds and delivers books to communities, you or anyone, anywhere!
data.title: Library Protocol

data.description:
OpenZeppelin Contracts is the most widely used library for secure and standardized smart contract development in the Ethereum ecosystem. First released in 2016, it has become the go-to resource for teams looking to build production-grade decentralized applications without having to reinvent the wheel for every token, governance mechanism, or upgradeable pattern. By leveraging rigorously tested code and well-established best practices, developers can focus on innovation while reducing their security risks.

Over the years, OpenZeppelin has expanded the library and its tooling with features like upgradeable contracts, interactive contract generation (through the Contracts Wizard), and new modules for emerging standards (e.g., ERC‑4337 for account abstraction). We have also expanded the library’s support beyond Solidity to include other smart contract languages, particularly Arbitrum Stylus.

Everything is backed by our dedication to security, demonstrated through ongoing audits, a robust community bug bounty, and advanced testing methods (including fuzzing and formal verification).
data.title: OpenZeppelin Contracts Library

data.name: Gitcoin
data.description: Gitcoin creates solutions that empower digitally native communities to fund, build, and protect what matters.

This project outlines the creation of a decentralized library for web3 books and resources, which leverages blockchain technology and decentralized storage to provide a censorship-resistant, accessible, and verifiable platform for users to access and share educational and informational content.

Key Features
Blockchain Integration: Use a blockchain platform, such as Ethereum, to manage metadata, provenance, and ownership of resources.
Decentralized Storage: Utilize IPFS (InterPlanetary File System) or Filecoin to store book and resource files, ensuring they are resistant to censorship.
Metadata Management: Store resource metadata on the blockchain, including title, author, description, and links to the decentralized storage locations.
Smart Contracts: Develop smart contracts to manage ownership, lending, and access rights to resources.
Access Control: Implement an access control system using non-fungible tokens (NFTs) or other access tokens to grant or deny access to resources.
User-Friendly Interface: Create an intuitive web3 interface that allows users to browse the library, check out resources, and interact with their web3 wallets. Lending and Borrowing: Implement a system for lending and borrowing resources, with due dates and penalties for late returns.
Review and Rating System: Add a review and rating system to allow users to provide feedback on resource quality.
Decentralized Identity: Utilize decentralized identity solutions for user authentication and profile management.
Search and Discovery: Implement search and discovery features to help users find specific resources.
Community Governance: Introduce a decentralized governance system where the community can propose and vote on resource additions, updates, or removals.
Content Verification: Use oracles or reputation systems to verify content authenticity and accuracy.
Legal Considerations: Address copyright and licensing issues, ensuring that content is distributed within legal boundaries.
Monetization: Determine sustainable revenue models, including access fees, donations, or token-based incentives.
Testing and Auditing: Conduct thorough testing and consider third-party security audits to ensure the platform's robustness.
User Education: Provide educational resources and guides to help users understand web3 technology and wallet usage.
Community Building: Foster a community of contributors, users, and advocates to support the growth and sustainability of the library.
Video Books
Short Online quiz
Earn NFTs
Live class / Tutorial Streaming

questions.explanation:
Library Protocol provides an innovative way of leveraging open source in web3 to build real life solutions that provides tremendous value to everyday people. 

Library Protocol codebase could become a model on how decentralized library systems can be built

questions.query: What features or use cases does your dApp/App present? How is it differentiated?
questions.explanation:
The ultimate goal of Library Protocol is to be a catalyst for global literacy and connection. Our vision is a world where every story finds its reader, and every reader finds their story. Here are some use cases of the platform and those that we envision. 


### A Book-sharing App

Imagine: Maria, a single mother in rural Mexico, who loves reading but has no local library. Using Library Protocol’s book-sharing app, she borrows a children’s book from a lender in Texas to read to her son, sparking his love for stories. The app’s intuitive interface makes it easy for her to request and return the book, bringing literature into her home for the first time.

### A Knowledge Sharing Network

Imagine: A group of university students in Nigeria forms a study circle on Library Protocol, sharing academic books with peers in South Africa and India. Through the knowledge-sharing network, they exchange notes and insights on sustainable agriculture, collaboratively writing a research paper that wins a regional award, all enabled by the platform’s global reach.

### A Vehicle for Getting Books to Places

Imagine: A refugee camp in Jordan lacks educational resources. Through Library Protocol, a volunteer in Germany sends 50 textbooks to the camp, using the platform to coordinate shipping and track delivery. The books arrive, providing children with their first access to science and math education, proving the platform’s power as a vehicle for getting books to places in need.

### Sharing Knowledge, Connecting Curious Minds

Imagine: An aspiring writer in the Philippines connects with a retired professor in Canada on Library Protocol. The professor lends a rare book on creative writing, and they engage in a discussion via the platform’s messaging feature. This exchange of knowledge inspires the writer to publish her first novel, showing how Library Protocol connects curious minds across borders.

### Your Bookshelf, Shared with the World!

Imagine: Kutubu, a book collector in Ghana, has a shelf of 200 books on African history. He lists them on Library Protocol, and within a month, his books are borrowed by readers in Brazil, Japan, and France. Kutubu’s collection—his bookshelf, shared with the world—helps global readers learn about his culture, fostering cross-cultural understanding.

### Read More, Access More

Imagine: Priya, a high school student in India, dreams of studying astronomy but can’t afford textbooks. On Library Protocol, she borrows a series of astronomy books from lenders in Australia and the UK, accessing resources she’d never find locally. This enables her to read more, access more, and eventually win a scholarship to a prestigious university.

### Decentralizing Access to Every Story

Imagine: A group of communities band together and pull funds together, purchasing 1000 copies of Vitalic's or Owocki's new book and shipping it to these communities based in various countries in Africa. 

### Library Protocol Turns Any Book Owner into a Library

Imagine: Sarah, a retiree in Scotland with a modest collection of 50 books, joins Library Protocol. She lists her books, and soon, readers from New Zealand to Nigeria are borrowing her novels and gardening guides. Sarah, once just a book owner, becomes a library, serving a global community and feeling a renewed sense of purpose in her retirement.

### Library Protocol is Redefining the Future of Libraries

Imagine: A small town in Brazil, unable to fund a public library, adopts Library Protocol as its library system. Residents share their personal collections, creating a decentralized library network that serves the entire community. This model—where libraries are no longer buildings but networks of people—shows how Library Protocol is redefining the future of libraries, making them more inclusive and resilient.

### A Decentralized Economy for Open Knowledge

Imagine: Jamal, a book owner in Morocco, lends his collection of 100 books on Library Protocol, earning tokens for each loan. He uses these tokens to fund a literacy program in his village, while borrowers contribute reviews that earn them tokens to access more books. This decentralized economy for open knowledge ensures that sharing books benefits everyone, creating a sustainable cycle of learning and giving back.

questions.query: What are your plans for further development, and how will the grant funds be used to achieve these goals?
questions.explanation:
Library Protocol is poised to grow from humble beginnings into a global movement that redefines the future of libraries and builds a decentralized economy for open knowledge. 

We are actively developing the next version of the dApp, which comes with lots of new features and innovations such as:

- Enhanced onchain borrowing & Lending of Books
- Enhanced version of Library Dashboard that provides more data and analytics of a libraries activities. 
- Enhanced version of reader profile including analytics of reading and borrowing activities
- Reputation System 
- Community features
- AI features
- And a lot more. 

### Use of Grant Funds
Development: Enhance the app’s usability, add more innovative and user-centric features.   

Community Outreach: Fund partnerships and marketing to grow our user base and increase our reach.  

Operations and Security: Support blockchain upgrades, security audits, and operational costs to ensure reliability.

questions.query: Provide a brief overview of your tool, library, or framework. What specific problem or inefficiency in the development process does it address?
questions.explanation:
OpenZeppelin Contracts provides secure, community-reviewed and audited implementations of common smart contract patterns: tokens (ERC20, ERC721, ERC1155), access control, governance modules, payment and finance primitives, and upgradeable proxies. These contracts are available in Solidity, Arbitrum Stylus and other smart contract languages.

By relying on time-tested and audited code, developers avoid duplicating foundational logic. This ensures consistent standards implementation and reduces the risk of exploits resulting from ad-hoc or unvetted smart contract code.

questions.query: How does your project reduce development barriers, improve efficiency, or enhance the security of Web3 projects? Please provide specific examples or metrics if available.
questions.explanation:
1. **Reduced Complexity**: Developers can import widely used implementations (e.g., ERC20 tokens) instead of writing them from scratch, saving development time and audit effort.
2. **Battle-Tested Security**: Over 99% test coverage, continuous fuzzing, formal verification on critical components, and six major audits across different releases.
3. **Ongoing Maintenance & Updates**: Our dedicated maintainers and active community quickly fix bugs, respond to new Solidity or EVM features, and introduce new standards (e.g., ERC‑7786).

By eliminating the need for projects to reinvent safe implementations of standards and patterns, we allow teams to concentrate on application-specific logic and innovation.

questions.query: Describe the current usage and support for your tool within the developer community. This could include GitHub stars, downloads, or testimonials from developers.
questions.explanation:
- **GitHub Stars**: Over 25k stars on the main [openzeppelin-contracts](https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/openzeppelin-contracts) repository.
- **GitHub Forks**: Over 12k forks on the main [openzeppelin-contracts](https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/openzeppelin-contracts) repository.
- **NPM Downloads**:
    - `@openzeppelin/contracts`: 54.9M+ downloads to date ([reference](https://npm-stat.com/charts.html?package=%40openzeppelin%2Fcontracts&from=2018-01-01&to=2025-03-01))
    - `@openzeppelin/contracts-upgradeable`: 18.2M+ downloads ([reference](https://npm-stat.com/charts.html?package=%40openzeppelin%2Fcontracts-upgradeable&from=2018-01-01&to=2025-03-01))
    - `@openzeppelin/hardhat-upgrades` & `@openzeppelin/foundry-upgrades`: 5M+ combined downloads ([reference](https://npm-stat.com/charts.html?package=%40openzeppelin%2Fhardhat-upgrades&from=2018-01-01&to=2025-03-01))
- **Dependent Repositories**: Over 295k public repositories depend on OpenZeppelin Contracts on GitHub. ([reference](https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/openzeppelin-contracts/network/dependents))
- **Total Value Transferred Via OpenZeppelin Contracts**: Over 22 trillion. ([Dune Analytics](https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/openzeppelin-contracts))
- **Testimonials & Education**:
    - Integrated into popular educational resources like [CryptoZombies](https://cryptozombies.io/) and [FreeCodeCamp’s blockchain course](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gyMwXuJrbJQ).
    - Endorsed by core contributors, DeFi protocols, and security researchers for its reliability and security rigor. ([reference](https://www.openzeppelin.com/solidity-contracts))

questions.query: Outline your project's roadmap and how the grant funds will be used to achieve your development goals.
questions.explanation:
1. **Continuous Release Cycle**:
    - **Contracts v5.2+**: Further expansions on cross-chain interoperability, cryptographic primitives, and deeper integration of account abstraction patterns (ERC‑4337).
    - **Community-Driven Experimental Modules**: Ongoing iteration on the new “community-contracts” repository, exploring next-generation ERC standards (e.g., ERC-7786 for cross-chain messaging).
2. **Security & Audits**:
    - Allocate additional audit weeks for upcoming major releases to maintain trust in new modules.
    - Expand formal verification coverage and advanced fuzz testing.
3. **Tooling & Integrations**:
    - Enhance the Hardhat and Foundry plugins for upgrades, ensuring frictionless deployment of upgradeable contracts with advanced validation.
    - Improve the “Contracts Wizard” to support new standards, simplifications for multichain deployments, and advanced UI for customizing governance modules.
    - Extend subgraph templates for more robust on-chain analytics of governance and token usage.
4. **Education & Community**:
    - Expand documentation and tutorials for advanced topics.
    - Facilitate more workshops and open community calls to gather feedback and promote best practices.

In general, all matching grants go directly into sustaining and improving the Contracts library (and closely related open-source tooling like Contracts Wizard and Hardhat/Foundry Plugins). This covers continuous development, audits, community support, documentation, new feature exploration, and addressing feedback from the Ethereum developer ecosystem.

questions.query: For any project deploying smart contracts on blockchain networks, please list all your deployer addresses and their corresponding blockchain networks. Use this format for each entry: [deployer_address], [chain_id]—for example, 0x123abc..., 42161 (This represents a deployer address on the Arbitrum network). Please include a separate line for each unique deployer address and blockchain combination.
questions.explanation: OpenZeppelin Contracts is a library that developers incorporate into their own deployments. We do not maintain a single canonical deployer address because each end-user or organization typically deploys contracts with their own EOA or multisig. Consequently, there is no single “official” deployment address for the library itself.
